author: By Amanda Taub
title: Coups Are on the Rise. Why?
description: A recent surge is surprising because successful coups are rare.
content: Following the news lately is enough to make one wonder if coups might be contagious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Rep. Lauren Boebert Is Ejected From ‘Beetlejuice’ After a Disturbance
description: The congresswoman was asked to leave after being accused of being loud and recording the show at a moment when many theaters are debating how to deal with raucous audience behavior.
content: Representative Lauren Boebert, a Republican firebrand from Colorado, was ejected from a touring production of the “Beetlejuice” musical in Denver last weekend, making her the latest case study in an evolving debate over how theaters should respond to raucous audience behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
title: Floods in Libya
description: At least 5,200 people have died and thousands more are missing.
content: The initial floods in northeastern Libya — after torrential rain this past weekend — were bad enough. But the worst of the damage was not a result of those floods. It has instead come from the subsequent bursting of two dams near the coastal city of Derna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Can Samantha Power Win the Battle for Ukraine’s Future?
description: A country’s postwar success would be a rebuke to the idea that the free world is in terminal decline.
content: Late on a muggy evening in mid-July, Samantha Power, administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, and Bridget Brink, the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, boarded a night train from Kyiv to Odesa, accompanied by a few staff members and a discreet security detail. Earlier that day, Ukrainian naval drones had damaged the bridge connecting Russia to occupied Crimea, the second such attack of the war. Hours later, the Kremlin announced it would not renew the Black Sea Grain Initiative, a deal brokered last year by Turkey and the United Nations that, in a little less than a year, had allowed Ukraine to export nearly 33 million tons of grain from its three major remaining ports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Chau Doan
title: Vietnam Apartment Block Fire Kills at Least 56 People
description: The fire broke out at a nine-story residential tower in Hanoi, the capital, late Tuesday night. State-run news media also reported that 37 others were injured.
content: A fire that broke out late Tuesday at a nine-story apartment tower in Hanoi, Vietnam, killed at least 56 people, potentially making it one of the country’s deadliest blazes in well over a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Pandemic Fraud May Have Robbed Unemployment Insurance of $135 Billion
description: As much as 15 percent in unemployment benefits paid during the pandemic could have been fraudulently obtained, according to a Government Accountability Office report.
content: More generous unemployment benefits doled out during the pandemic appear to have been a magnet for fraud, according to a government watchdog report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: The toll of flooding in Libya.
content: More than 5,000 people were killed in Libya after torrential rain caused two dams to burst near the coastal city of Derna, destroying much of the city and carrying entire neighborhoods into the sea, local authorities said. Floodwaters also swept through other eastern settlements, including Shahhat, Al-Bayda and Marj. At least 20,000 people were displaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: W.N.B.A. Playoff Preview: Two Teams to Rule Them All
description: The Aces and the Liberty towered above the competition this season. Will they meet in the finals?
content: Two superteams, the Las Vegas Aces and the New York Liberty, dominated the W.N.B.A. season, as expected. They were so good that only two others teams in the 12-team league even managed a winning record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: How Yotam Ottolenghi Was Seduced by Soba Noodles
description: The somewhat magical noodles have an innate generosity: add whatever you feel like at the moment.
content: I started cooking soba noodles long before I experienced the real deal. (I say this with a pinch of salt — or soy? — because I am not a food purist. I don’t believe there’s an ultimate way to cook anything.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: F.B.I. Agent Undercuts Claims of Political Interference in Hunter Biden Inquiry
description: Thomas Sobocinski, an F.B.I. agent, told House investigators that the prosecutor overseeing the investigation into the president’s son never said he did not have full authority to pursue charges.
content: A high-ranking F.B.I. agent has provided testimony to the House Judiciary Committee that contradicts a key claim made by an I.R.S. agent who said that political interference had hampered the investigation into the taxes of Hunter Biden, the president’s son, dealing a blow to House Republicans’ wide-ranging inquiry into the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Rising Gas Prices Provide Fodder for Republican Criticism of Biden
description: An expected jump in the latest inflation reading will almost certainly provoke broadsides from Republicans who hammered Mr. Biden over high gas prices throughout last summer.
content: The big headache of President Biden’s Summer of 2022 — high gasoline prices — may once again bedevil him this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: McCarthy Reversal on Impeachment Inquiry Reflects Pressure From the Right
description: The speaker, who formerly argued that the House must vote before opening an impeachment inquiry, changed his tune this week, a decision that could have consequences for the investigation.
content: When Democrats declared in 2019 that they were moving ahead with an impeachment inquiry into President Donald J. Trump without a House vote, Representative Kevin McCarthy, then the minority leader, railed against the move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Climate Law Is Reshaping Private Investment in the United States
description: Lucrative tax incentives have fueled a surge in solar panels but failed to boost wind power, data from a new project show.
content: Private investment in clean energy projects like solar panels, hydrogen power and electric vehicles surged after President Biden signed an expansive climate bill into law last year, a development that shows how tax incentives and federal subsidies have helped reshape some consumer and corporate spending in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Ukraine Strikes the Headquarters of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet in Crimea
description: The Russian Ministry of Defense said that it had shot down seven of 10 cruise missiles that Ukraine fired at the facility in the city of Sevastopol. The area hosts naval operations key to Moscow’s war efforts in Ukraine.
content: A Ukrainian attack targeting the headquarters of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet in Crimea damaged two ships and triggered a large blaze at a sprawling naval shipyard that plays a critical role in the Russian war effort, according to Russian and Ukrainian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Russia Overcomes Sanctions to Expand Missile Production, Officials Say
description: Moscow’s missile production now exceeds prewar levels, officials say, leaving Ukraine especially vulnerable this coming winter.
content: Russia has managed to overcome sanctions and export controls imposed by the West to expand its missile production beyond prewar levels, according to U.S., European and Ukrainian officials, leaving Ukraine especially vulnerable to intensified attacks in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Why Floods Can Turn So Deadly, So Fast
description: The flooding in Libya shows how climate, geography and other factors can collide with swift and disastrous results.
content: A powerful storm hit Libya’s northeast coast on Sunday. Two dams burst upstream from the port city of Derna, causing a torrential flood that has killed more than 5,000 people, according to local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Saratoga Springs, N.Y.: An Urban Oasis at the Foot of the Adirondacks
description: The Saratoga Race Course has long been a big draw, but it’s not the only one in this small, walkable city with a ‘phenomenal quality of life.’
content: For more than 30 years, Gregory and Loretta Smith were regular visitors to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., traveling from their home in Rockland County on weekends and summer holidays to attend the horse races and enjoy the pace of life in this small city about three hours north of Manhattan. Once they had both retired — he from his job as a deputy warden at Rikers Island in 2004, and she from her media technology job in New York City earlier this year — they were finally able to turn their favorite getaway into a more permanent home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Dozens of Subway Windows Are Smashed in $500,000 Vandalism Spree
description: M.T.A. officials said windows were broken on 45 trains, disrupting commutes for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers.
content: Vandals smashed dozens of train windows along several subway lines, causing half a million dollars in damage and disrupting the commutes of hundreds of thousands of passengers on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Kevin McCarthy Faces His Puppet Master
description: “Live to fight another day” seems to be the House speaker’s guiding principle.
content: Is it just me, or did Kevin McCarthy look a little rough around the edges on Tuesday when announcing his decision to open an impeachment investigation into President Biden?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: French Pianist Wins Surprise, Prestigious $300,000 Award
description: Alexandre Kantorow, 26, joins an esteemed group of pianists who have won the Gilmore Artist Award, which is given every four years.
content: The 26-year-old French pianist Alexandre Kantorow was not exactly sure what the man from Kalamazoo, Mich., wanted when he invited him to lunch last spring in Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Christie and the Boss: A One-Sided Jersey Relationship Warms Up (Sort Of)
description: The former New Jersey governor idolizes Bruce Springsteen, but their political differences have led to frostiness. Now, according to Chris Christie, their relationship is “a good one.”
content: Chris Christie has been to more than 150 Bruce Springsteen concerts, knows the words to every song and treasures the ticket stubs he has collected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Santos, on CNN, Clashes With Interviewer and Strikes Fighting Pose
description: Representative George Santos denied any “negotiation” with prosecutors over the charges facing him.
content: In the months since Representative George Santos’s series of lies and exaggerations were exposed, he has adopted a defiant stance toward reporters, accusing the news media of leading a biased crusade against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Theater Troupe That’s Also a Support Network for Exiles
description: The leaders of the Belarus Free Theater, who fled the country more than a decade ago, are helping more recent refugees to rebuild their lives while putting on a new show.
content: When the two founders of the renowned Belarus Free Theater claimed political asylum in Britain in 2011, they found themselves homeless, with few possessions and facing a bureaucratic labyrinth before they could work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: State Dept. Defends Limited Release of Iranian Funds for Prisoners
description: Republicans are complaining about a key step toward completing a deal that will give Tehran access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes.
content: The State Department on Tuesday defended its progress toward completing a prisoner deal with Iran under which the United States is freeing $6 billion in frozen Iranian funds for humanitarian purposes in exchange for the release of five Americans held in Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: MTV Video Music Awards: 5 Memorable Moments
description: Nicki Minaj hosted and helped close out a nearly four-hour show heavy on performances and reaction shots of Taylor Swift in the audience.
content: The MTV Video Music Awards returned to the Prudential Center in Newark on Tuesday night, as Nicki Minaj hosted a nearly four-hour show that included the members of ’N Sync coming together to present a Moon Person trophy to Taylor Swift (who gushed directly to the boy band, “I had your dolls”) and Sean Combs receiving a global icon honor (and telling the crowd his career had humble beginnings, as a paperboy). The Brazilian pop star Anitta delivered one of the event’s most solid one-liners — “I want to thank myself because I worked so hard,” she said in an acceptance speech — which she also proved onstage, performing both a solo medley and a collaboration with the K-pop group Tomorrow X Together. At the end of the night, the following five moments stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: U.S. Deepens Security Pledge to Bahrain, an Adversary of Iran
description: The promise to defend Bahrain could serve as a template for other Gulf countries like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which are also pressing for stronger American security commitments.
content: The Biden administration signed a security agreement with the Gulf kingdom of Bahrain on Wednesday, pledging its commitment to defend the authoritarian country from attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Police officers posed for a photo with the fugitive after his capture.
description: In the immediate aftermath of the manhunt for Danelo Cavalcante, a peculiar scene unfolded — some two dozen law enforcement agents in tactical gear clustered around the fugitive. One, holding the leash of a canine, nudged his way to the front. Another knelt with a rifle that had been recovered. A third officer handed off his cellphone to a colleague before joining the group. Then everyone posed for a photo.
content: In the immediate aftermath of the manhunt for Danelo Cavalcante, a peculiar scene unfolded — some two dozen law enforcement agents in tactical gear clustered around the fugitive. One, holding the leash of a canine, nudged his way to the front. Another knelt with a rifle that had been recovered. A third officer handed off his cellphone to a colleague before joining the group. Then everyone posed for a photo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: 2024’s Field of Nightmares
description: What a harsh truth from baseball says about Biden and Trump.
content: In the bottom of the 10th inning of the sixth game of the 1986 World Series, with the Boston Red Sox leading the New York Mets 5-3, Red Sox manager John McNamara sent Bill Buckner — a great hitter dealing with terrible leg problems that made him gimp his way around first base — back out to play the infield instead of putting in Dave Stapleton, Buckner’s defensive replacement. A half-dozen at-bats later, a Mookie Wilson ground ball went through Buckner’s wobbly legs, sending the World Series to Game 7 and a certain 6-year-old Red Sox fan to bed in desperate tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Choe Sang-Hun
title: Putin and Kim Find Common Ground in Hostility Toward the West
description: The two leaders trumpeted their ties in a summit that signaled a new era in their relationship, amid speculation that North Korea would send more weapons to Moscow for its war in Ukraine.
content: They gazed into the workings of a rocket launchpad. They tucked into crab dumplings, sturgeon and entrecôte. And they lifted their glasses at a flower-lined table in the conference room of a remote Russian spaceport, toasting the Kremlin’s “sacred struggle” against a “band of evil,” otherwise known as the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Easy Vegetarian Pasta Is Full of Brilliant Hacks
description: A snap to throw together, this lively dish takes the best parts of pasta salad and makes them a whole lot better, Melissa Clark writes.
content: What is it about pasta salad that makes it such a divisive dish? Is it that the many bad versions out there — soggy noodles swathed in bottled dressing and tossed with wan vegetables — make good ones hard to imagine? Or maybe since the dish reached peak popularity in the 1980s, the entire category seems about as glamorous as a home perm on a humid afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: It’s a Spider, Not a Doctor, Captain or Vulcan
description: On their mission to seek out new life, scientists have named three new spider species Kirk, Spock and McCoy — after characters from the original “Star Trek” series.
content: Star Trek fans and spider enthusiasts have unexpectedly converged on a new frontier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The One Privilege Liberals Ignore
description: We can’t have a serious conversation about poverty and inequality without contemplating the breakdown of marriage and family.
content: American liberals have led the campaign to reduce child poverty since Franklin Roosevelt, and it’s a proud legacy. But we have long had a blind spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Schumer to Lead Senate Delegation to China Amid Tensions
description: The Senate majority leader, a longtime China hawk, plans to visit Beijing in the fall in another high-level visit as the Biden administration tries to improve diplomatic ties.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, is planning to lead a bipartisan delegation of senators to China this fall, making him the highest-level congressional official and the latest senior statesman to visit the United States’ rival superpower as the Biden administration attempts to address tensions with Beijing through an all-out diplomatic push.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: Piano-Playing Hot-Air Balloon Aerialists? Rochester Fringe Festival Is Back.
description: With its commitment to presenting free spectacles, the event has become one of the country’s more prominent multidisciplinary events.
content: Sweaty venues roughly the size of a walk-in closet. Eye-catchingly daft titles. Lampposts all but sagging under the weight of promotional fliers. Drunken Shakespeare mash-ups and earnest solo shows. Volunteers shooing audiences onto the street in order to air out those closet-size venues before the next performance, and the one after that, and the one after that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: A Party With a Lot of Baggage
description: Martha Stewart, Spike Lee, Jenna Lyons and Justin Theroux gathered for an event for Rimowa in Chelsea, the luggage brand to the stars.
content: “Nothing has a vibe anymore,” Carlos Quirarte said last Thursday, quickly adding the disclaimer that “people use the word vibe, or whatever, way too much.’’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Infinite Life’ Review: Is There a Cure for Pain and Desire?
description: Illness is no metaphor, and neither is pleasure, in Annie Baker’s weird and great new play set at a fasting clinic.
content: A woman collapsed in a chaise longue on a brick and breeze-block patio is trying to read George Eliot’s “Daniel Deronda.” Over several days, various acquaintances also taking the sun will ask her what the book is about, a question she finds hard to answer as she keeps getting stuck on page 152. Still, she calls the novel “very weird and great.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Evan Gershkovich’s family appeals to the U.N. for help in securing his release.
description: The Wall Street Journal reporter’s parents and sister visited the U.N. just days before world leaders arrive for the annual General Assembly.
content: The family of Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter who has been detained in Russia since March, appealed on Wednesday for the United Nations’ help in bringing him home, urging world leaders who will soon be attending the U.N. General Assembly to join the call for his release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: An Israeli TV Channel for Netanyahu Fans Rapidly Gains Influence
description: Channel 14, formerly a small and niche outlet, has turned into a major force in the public discourse of a deeply divided country.
content: Israel’s military command? Part of a liberal-left “deep state.” The country’s judiciary? “Mafioso.” And the thousands of Israelis protesting a polarizing judicial overhaul plan introduced by the far-right government? Privileged, elitists — and anarchists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: A Hidden Reason Cities Fall Apart
description: The loss of civic and corporate elites played a huge role in the erosion of urban life.
content: Once-vibrant cities like St. Louis, Baltimore and Cleveland have suffered from poverty, crime, depopulation, social dysfunction and homelessness for decades — setbacks compounded by the decline of manufacturing, the nationalization of local banks and waves of corporate acquisitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Alexandra Alter
title: Drew Barrymore Dropped as National Book Awards Host After Strike Backlash
description: The actor and TV host’s decision to return her talk show to the air, bypassing striking writers, made her a magnet for criticism, online and off.
content: Drew Barrymore has been dropped as the host of the National Book Awards, the foundation that presents the prizes said Tuesday, after the actress received a barrage of criticism for deciding to bring back her daytime talk show despite the strike by television writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Why Are So Many Millennials Going to Mongolia?
description: In an era of Instagram tourism, some young people are searching for less curated travel experiences. So they’re flocking to the open spaces of this East Asian nation.
content: It was near midnight, in a storm, on a dirt road in the middle of Mongolia. Still, the river seemed manageable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mandy K. Cohen
title: As a Doctor, a Mother and the Head of the C.D.C., I Recommend That You Get the Latest Covid Booster
description: Here’s why the latest booster is recommended for more Americans.
content: We have come a long way since the early days of 2020. Back then, I was the head of North Carolina’s Department of Health and Human Services and working alongside Gov. Roy Cooper to navigate the uncertainty, the challenges and the fear around Covid-19. My extended family was in New York, the epicenter of the U.S. outbreak. I didn’t realize then that it would be over a year until I saw them in person again. All I wanted was for them to be safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Who Is the GOAT?
description: Brady. Serena. LeBron. Messi. We invite you to make a case for the greatest athlete ever.
content: Who is the GOAT?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: zenith
description: This word has appeared in 34 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word zenith has appeared in 34 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 4 in “Acropolis Will Limit Visitor Numbers as Europe Tackles a Tourist Crush” by Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: The U.A.W. Could Go on Strike on Friday. Here’s What to Know.
description: The union and the carmakers remain far apart on wages.
content: The United Auto Workers union, which represents about 150,000 workers at U.S. car plants, could strike against three of the country’s largest automakers on Friday if the union and the companies are unable to reach new contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Senator’s Blockade of Military Promotions Begins to Cut Deep
description: Tommy Tuberville of Alabama has refused to lift his hold unless the Pentagon cancels a policy ensuring that service members have access to abortion.
content: Near the river entrance of the outermost ring of the Pentagon, where visiting dignitaries are greeted with full honors, the hallways that usually house photos of senior military leaders are more bare these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Taylor Swift and Beyoncé Get Their Own Press Corps
description: Newspapers rarely assign a reporter to cover a single artist. But Swift and Beyoncé are cultural forces whose tours continue breaking records.
content: Gannett, the largest newspaper chain in the United States, has announced that it would hire reporters to cover two of the biggest names in music: Taylor Swift and Beyoncé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Boom Times
description: Guilherme Gilioli hides the right answers in plain sight.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Sped Up as Gas Prices Rose
description: Consumer prices rose 3.7 percent in the year through August, marking another month of accelerating inflation. The Federal Reserve will closely parse the data as it prepares its next interest-rate decision.
content: Federal Reserve officials are likely to remain wary about the outlook for inflation after a report released Wednesday: Overall price increases sped up because of a pop in gas prices in August, and a more closely watched index that strips out volatile food and fuel prices climbed at a faster monthly pace than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: What Can Turmeric Actually Do for Your Health?
description: A new study concluded that it could be effective at alleviating stomach discomfort. But a lot is unknown.
content: Turmeric has been used as a spice and medicine for thousands of years. And in recent decades, it’s become popular as a dietary supplement, often sold as curcumin — a chemical compound found in dried turmeric — with claims that it can soothe joint pain, reduce inflammation and improve mobility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Husband of Rep. Mary Peltola Is Killed in Plane Crash, Officials Say
description: Eugene Peltola Jr., 57, died after the small plane he was piloting crashed in a remote area near St. Mary’s, Alaska, on Tuesday, federal officials said.
content: The husband of Representative Mary Peltola, Democrat of Alaska, died on Wednesday morning after the single-engine plane he was flying crashed shortly after takeoff in a mountainous area of southwestern Alaska, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Libyan Flood Survivor Recounts Horror After Dams Burst
description: “We walked out barefoot and saw our friends and neighbors dying,” said a woman from the hard-hit city of Derna. More than 5,000 are reported dead and 10,000 more are believed to be missing.
content: As two dams collapsed and storm waters tore through the streets of the Libyan city of Derna, carrying bodies and buildings with them, Ruba Hatem Yassine, her pregnant sister and several older relatives clambered up a neighbor’s ladder to the roof to flee the grasp of the rushing flood below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Citi, Falling Behind Peers, Unveils ‘Uncomfortable’ Changes and Layoffs
description: The bank’s chief executive, Jane Fraser, said the lender had grown bloated and needlessly bureaucratic.
content: Citigroup unveiled a wide-ranging management shake-up on Wednesday, and its chief executive, Jane Fraser, admitted in unusually frank terms that the bank was headed in the wrong direction and said that for the foreseeable future her employees “might not enjoy it so much.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: New Trade-In Program Would Aim to Prevent E-Bike Fires
description: The City Council is expected to approve a multi-million-dollar city program to try to get unsafe e-bikes and batteries off the streets.
content: The City Council will move on Thursday to create the first New York City-run trade-in program for electric bikes and lithium-ion batteries, which have started deadly fires. It would begin this year, run for two years and provide e-bikes and batteries that have been certified to industry standards for free, or at a low cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Charles Drew University in South Los Angeles Starts Its Own Medical School
description: The historically Black institution welcomed its inaugural class of 60 medical students this summer.
content: When it comes to diversity, California’s medical work force looks far different from the state’s wider population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: California Lawmakers Vote to Require Disclosure of Greenhouse Emissions
description: Under the measure, companies would have to publicly report their climate pollution. Gov. Gavin Newsom’s office would not say whether he plans to sign the bill.
content: The California Legislature this week passed a landmark bill that would require major companies to publicly disclose their greenhouse gas emissions, a move with national and global repercussions in governments’ efforts to fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin, Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: Marquee Writers Push for Negotiations, but Their Clout May Not Matter
description: Some showrunners, eager for progress in the Hollywood strike, want the Writers Guild of America to meet with studios. How much sway they still have is in question.
content: With the Hollywood writers’ strike stretching into its fifth month and the financial toll on people across the entertainment industry becoming increasingly grim, A-list showrunners have grown impatient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Top E.U. Official Calls for Major Expansion of Bloc
description: In an address, Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, expressed support for Ukraine and several other nations joining the bloc over the next few years.
content: The European Union’s top official on Wednesday called for a major expansion of the bloc to include not only Ukraine but also Moldova, several Western Balkan nations and Georgia over the next few years, a move that would push the group from 27 to over 30 members with more than half a billion citizens, and would make the world’s largest free-trade, free-travel area even larger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Expecting Cannabis Boom, New York Lays Down the Rules
description: The New York Cannabis Control Board approved a package of regulations that included licensing requirements for distributors, dispensaries and others.
content: Cannabis regulators in New York approved a package of regulations Tuesday that laid the groundwork for an expansion of the state’s emerging cannabis industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Dublin Marathon Medals Commemorate Yeats, and Misquote Him
description: Those who complete this year’s race in October will receive a medal that reads, “There are no strangers here; only friends you haven’t met yet.”
content: Those who complete this year’s Irish Life Dublin Marathon will come away from the race with a number of rewards: The satisfaction of having trained for and accomplished a 26.2 mile run, the relief of being finished — and a prize medal commemorating the Irish poet William Butler Yeats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Even in Remote Areas, Civilians Lead Rescue in Wake of Earthquake
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 13, 2023.
content: “I went expecting misery. But I found Moroccan solidarity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Standoff Over Electric Vehicle Workers Poses Risk for Biden
description: A looming auto industry strike could test the president’s commitment to making electric vehicles a source of well-paying union jobs.
content: President Biden has been highly attuned to the politics of electric vehicles, helping to enact billions in subsidies to create new manufacturing jobs and going out of his way to court the United Automobile Workers union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: A Professor’s Remarks on Sexual Consent Stir Controversy. Now He’s Banned From Campus.
description: Stephen Kershnar, who teaches philosophy, is suing for the right to return to SUNY at Fredonia. The university defends its ban as necessary for safety.
content: Stephen Kershnar, a philosophy professor, is in academic purgatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: He Was a Hillary Clinton Cheerleader. Now He Calls Democrats a Threat.
description: Peter Daou, a former Democratic activist, is running Cornel West’s third-party campaign. He talked to The New York Times about how he came to view the two-party system as a bigger problem than Donald J. Trump.
content: On Monday, Cornel West, a left-wing scholar and third-party presidential candidate, announced that he had hired Peter Daou as his campaign manager. The choice adds a new twist to one of the most unusual career trajectories in political consulting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Former Buildings Chief Accused of Trading Favors for $150,000 in Bribes
description: The former commissioner, Eric Ulrich, pleaded not guilty, as did five other men, several of whom raised money for the campaign of Mayor Eric Adams.
content: Eric Ulrich rose through the ranks of city government with modest momentum, first elected as a city councilman before Mayor Eric Adams appointed him a senior adviser and, finally, his commissioner of the Department of Buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘Wrestlers’ Is Greg Whiteley’s Latest Underdog Tale
description: The director’s sports docu-series, like “Last Chance U” and “Cheer,” deliver high-stakes drama on and off the field. His new one explores a regional pro wrestling outfit.
content: When Greg Whiteley was 19 he ventured from his hometown, Bellevue, Wash., to spread the word of the Mormon Church on Navajo reservations in the Southwest. At first he would come in hot, as the kids say, eager to knock on doors and proselytize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.8 Million Homes in Rhode Island, California and Colorado
description: A 1750 house in Newport, a Craftsman bungalow in Carmel and a Tudor Revival home in Denver.
content: This house is less than half a block from the water, on a street lined with some of the city’s oldest homes. It is within easy walking distance of a public park, public beaches and Newport Harbor. The Gilded Age mansions of Bellevue Avenue, many open to the public, are less than 10 minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: El Chapo’s Wife Was Released After Nearly Two Years in Prison
description: Emma Coronel Aispuro pleaded guilty in 2021 to helping run her husband’s drug empire.
content: Emma Coronel Aispuro, the wife of the infamous Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, was released from a halfway house on Wednesday, almost two years after she was sentenced to prison for her role in her husband’s multibillion-dollar criminal empire and participating in his escape from custody in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Disabled Colleague Is Struggling at Work. Am I Responsible for Her Care?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what a workplace owes an employee with serious health challenges.
content: I have a co-worker with a rare, degenerative neurological disorder. For a decade, her decline was slow. But in the past five years, she has experienced a more rapid deterioration in both cognitive and physical capabilities. She is now struggling with her work in almost every way. The company makes every accommodation possible — deadlines are extended, errors forgiven and excuses entertained. We are a small company with limited employees, but because of her mostly pleasant demeanor and length of service, we have all tried to pitch in over the years and help in different ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Federal Judge Again Rules DACA Is Illegal
description: The judge maintained that President Barack Obama exceeded his authority when he created the program, which has allowed thousands of young undocumented immigrants to avoid deportation and work legally.
content: A federal judge in Texas on Wednesday rejected the Biden administration’s latest effort to save a program that has shielded hundreds of thousands of undocumented young adults from deportation, saying that it remained unlawful even after recent changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Birkenstock, German Maker of Iconic Sandals, Files for I.P.O. in New York
description: By going public on the N.Y.S.E., the brand is seeking to build on its reputation as a family-owned German business equally at home as on the fashion catwalks.
content: Birkenstock, the German shoemaker whose sandals have long been known as the brand favored by hippies and increasingly by hipsters, has filed for an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange, reflecting the company’s aim to raise its global profile while still retaining its roots in Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Economic Impact of an Auto Strike Could Be Felt Nationwide
description: An extended walkout by the United Auto Workers in a contract dispute could raise car prices and affect jobs at the companies’ suppliers.
content: Two years after the auto industry survived the supply-chain upheaval of the pandemic, another disruption — the prospective strike by the United Auto Workers — threatens to upend the production and distribution of new cars, and the impact could be wide-ranging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: What the Wildfire Stole From One Maui Family
description: A 7-year-old boy, his mom and grandparents tried to flee Hawaii’s deadliest wildfire in over a century, and ran into impossible challenges.
content: The wind had never felt so fierce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amisha Padnani
title: Have an Idea for an Overlooked Obituary? We Want Your Suggestions
description: The series, which recalls the lives of extraordinary people in history whose deaths were not noted by The Times, is seeking your nominations.
content: Ida B. Wells was a pioneering investigative journalist who took on racism in the Deep South with powerful reporting on lynchings, but when she died she did not get an obituary in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Charlie Savage
title: Ramaswamy Says He Would Fire Most of the Federal Work Force if Elected
description: Vivek Ramaswamy, whose campaign for the Republican nomination has gained attention in recent months, has vowed to dismantle much of the federal government and shutter key agencies.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, the Republican presidential candidate whose strident and sometimes unrealistic proposals have helped him stand out in the crowded primary field, said in a policy speech on Wednesday that he would fire more than 75 percent of the federal work force and shutter several major agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kevin McCarthy’s Impeachment Gambit: ‘A Dubious Mission in Search of a Crime’
description: Reaction to the speaker’s announcement of an inquiry into President Biden. Also: Children and freedom; the national popular vote; “women,” not “girls.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Len Chandler, an Early Fixture of the Folk Revival, Dies at 88
description: A singer who performed alongside Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and Pete Seeger, he was known for his topical songs, some of which he wrote in minutes.
content: Len Chandler, who was an early fixture of the folk music revival that swept through Greenwich Village in the late 1950s and ’60s and who sang alongside Pete Seeger, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and other higher-profile stars at civil rights marches and Vietnam War protests, died on Aug. 28 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Tells Trump to Use Secure Facility for Secret Evidence in Documents Case
description: Judge Aileen Cannon’s order did not specify where the former president could discuss the classified material but suggested it should not be Mar-a-Lago.
content: For the past few weeks, lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump and federal prosecutors have been arguing about a touchy subject: Should Mr. Trump, accused of mishandling classified documents, be allowed to discuss the secret papers with his lawyers in the secure facility he once used as president at Mar-a-Lago — the very place the F.B.I. swooped down on last summer to retrieve some of the records after he failed to return them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt de la Peña
title: ‘Mexikid’ and ‘Salsa Magic’ Drive Latino Kids to Their Roots
description: A Mexican American family heads to Jalisco in their Winnebago and a “bruja” from Puerto Rico steps out of a cab in Brooklyn.
content: When I was a kid, my family moved from a predominantly Mexican American border community in San Diego to a sleepy beach town 20 miles up the coast. Surrounded by the dominant culture for the first time, I found myself gravitating toward the “American” part of my Mexican American identity. I dropped soccer for basketball. Started asking out of church. Requested ham for Christmas dinners in addition to our usual tamales and empanadas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: Modi Wants to Make India a Chip-Making Superpower. Can He?
description: India’s government, seizing on the world’s desire to reduce reliance on China, is offering billions to build an entire semiconductor ecosystem on vast empty plots.
content: In his office in New Delhi, Ashwini Vaishnaw, the Indian minister of electronics and information technology, keeps a 12-inch disc of silicon semiconductor on the wall, gleaming like a platinum record beside a portrait of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Its circuits, measured in nanometers and invisible to the human eye, may be the most sophisticated objects ever made. It vies with oil as one of most valuable traded goods on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘We Benefited From Legacy Admissions. And We Want It to End.’
description: The Supreme Court ended race-based affirmative action in college admissions. Should legacy admissions, preferences for the children of alumni, end too?
content: The U.S. Supreme Court ruling ending race-conscious admissions in June placed a spotlight on legacy preferences in higher education, a practice that mostly helps white and wealthy students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Am Dating a Student’s Newly Separated Father. When Do We Spill?
description: A reader who works with children wonders when she and her boyfriend should reveal their new relationship to his family, including his child who is in her care.
content: I am a divorced mother with two kids. I own a business in which I work with children, and I started dating the father of a student recently. Admittedly, this is a delicate situation, but so far, it has been good for us. He told me he loves me, but I didn’t say it back: It feels too soon. He separated from his wife of 23 years and the mother of his kids just three months ago. (I know this can be a turbulent time.) Aside from concerns about my own heart, I worry how our news may affect his family. I have worked with his young son for several years and don’t want to breach his trust or make the divorce more difficult. I know it’s not my job to communicate with his family, but when should we tell them about our relationship — in the interest of living an honest life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: How Pharoah Sanders Beckoned the Gods on the Intimate ‘Pharoah’
description: The three-song 1976 recording arrives in a new boxed set at what seems a perfect moment to deepen our appreciation for the saxophonist’s role in music history.
content: In trying to capture what lay at the powerful core of the saxophonist Pharoah Sanders’s music, the British journalist Valerie Wilmer once referenced a conversation with a Nigerian composer. “In all ritual song there is that slow beat, trying to call the gods,” the (unnamed) musician had told her. “There’s no rush. It’s a slow process, as though one is praying.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Fine Art of Naming a Group Chat
description: As texting continues to be central to our social circles, the name and image attached are often more considered than the messages themselves.
content: The first thing RJ McLaughlin did when he was back on campus in late August for his junior year at Ramapo College of New Jersey was make a group chat for himself and the three guys with whom he shares a dormitory apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Guts,’ Part 2
description: A deep dive into whom the singer’s new songs might be about — and if it matters. Plus: Zach Bryan’s breakthrough and recent arrest.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Romney to Retire, Calling for a ‘New Generation’ Beyond Biden and Trump
description: The Utah Republican and 2012 G.O.P. presidential nominee, 76, said he would step aside to make way for younger leaders and strongly suggested that the president and former president should, too.
content: Senator Mitt Romney of Utah, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee who made a historic break with his party when he voted to remove former President Donald J. Trump from office, announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election in 2024, saying he wanted to make way for a “new generation of leaders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marshall
title: A Fashion Designer Who ‘Chose Crazy’
description: During the pandemic, Marco Ribeiro swapped restrained tailoring for vibrant, joyous creations.
content: It was during Paris’s first pandemic lockdown that the fashion designer Marco Ribeiro felt he’d reached a creative inflection point. “I was like, ‘I can go one of two ways,’” he recalls. “ ‘Either very commercial’ — but nobody was buying anything at the time, and nobody knew how long that would last — ‘or very crazy.’ I chose crazy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Matt Olson Did Something Even Hank Aaron Couldn’t Do
description: Olson, Atlanta’s slugging first baseman, hit his 51st home run of the season, tying the franchise record.
content: On Tuesday night, Matt Olson tied the Braves’ franchise record for home runs in a season, with 51. Trivia time: Whose record did he tie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘A Haunting in Venice’ Review: A Whodunit With a Splash of Horror
description: Kenneth Branagh directs and stars in this adaptation of a ghostly mystery from Agatha Christie, with assists from Michelle Yeoh and Tina Fey.
content: What genre does “A Haunting in Venice” belong to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Deadly Floods in Libya, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: A Spectacular Marble Cube Rises at Ground Zero
description: The Perelman Performing Arts Center, a glamorous $500 million project, may yet turn the World Trade Center into a neighborhood, our critic writes.
content: The new Perelman Performing Arts Center is the most glamorous civic building to land in New York in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Aubrey Plaza Has Found Her Scene Partner
description: For her stage debut in “Danny and the Deep Blue Sea,” the “White Lotus” actress is joining forces with Christopher Abbott. “We’re both unafraid to be ugly and weird and strange,” he said.
content: “Oh, put it down. Down the hatch,” Aubrey Plaza said while eating pizza for breakfast, in a downtown Los Angeles restaurant that was otherwise deserted on a late-August Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: People Don’t Want to Be Teachers Anymore. Can You Blame Them?
description: We’re in a ‘moment of really acute crisis’ for the profession.
content: Every week, it seems as if there’s another disturbing story about how difficult it is to be a teacher in 21st-century America. I’m not talking about the typical day-to-day work of teaching core subjects to children with varied academic and emotional needs — which is already a demanding job, made more so in the challenging aftermath of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Finding ‘Ghost Collaborators’ for an All-American Ballet
description: Matthew Lutz-Kinoy’s “Filling Station” has new choreography and music but converses with the 1938 original and its “glimmer of queer liberation.”
content: In American dance history, the 1938 ballet “Filling Station” is something between a milestone and a footnote. Made for American dancers by an American choreographer with a score by an American composer — a rare combination then — it was also novel in theme, about the interactions of local characters at a gas station. It was a pioneering work, and a popular one, that has become an infrequently revived curio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘When You Follow the Money, What Do You Find?’ and Other Questions About Trump
description: Norman Eisen answers questions about the key players in Trump’s election scheme.
content: Last month, Times Opinion published a graphic mapping out many of the key players in former President Donald Trump’s plot to upend the 2020 election. In response to the project, we received more than 700 questions and comments from readers hungry to know more. Some asked why key players had not yet been charged. Others wanted to know how to prevent future subversive efforts like the fake electors scheme. So we asked Norman Eisen, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who drew up the initial list of names and worked on how to arrange them, to weigh in. He started with the questions that, as he put it, “hit hardest for me: questions about who we left out and those who funded the whole shebang.” Reader comments have been lightly edited for length and clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: What We Know About the Deadly Floods in Libya
description: At least 5,200 people were killed, and at least 30,000 were displaced. Heavy rain caused two dams to break, devastating the coastal city of Derna.
content: Torrential rain from a storm that swept across the Mediterranean Sea over the weekend caused two dams to burst near Derna, a coastal city in northeast Libya, killing at least 5,200 people and washing entire neighborhoods out to sea. At least 10,000 more people were estimated to be missing in Derna and other flooded areas, the head of a government agency said, citing official estimates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francheska Melendez and Kathleen Massara
title: A Picasso Masterpiece That Visitors Can Finally Photograph
description: The Reina Sofía museum in Madrid has lifted its ban on photographing “Guernica,” saying it hopes to enhance the experience for those viewing the antiwar painting.
content: “No foto!” was long the refrain from guards at the Reina Sofía museum in Madrid if a visitor dared to attempt to take a picture of “Guernica,” Picasso’s 1937 antiwar masterpiece. But as one couple took a selfie on Wednesday and another woman adjusted her hair while smiling shyly into her phone’s camera, those guards were relaxed, offering tips about audio guides rather than yelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: China Denies Banning iPhones, but Cites Unspecified Security Concerns
description: The comments marked Beijing’s first public response to reports that some government agencies have told employees not to use iPhones for work.
content: China on Wednesday made its first public comments about reports that the government is restricting the use of Apple’s iPhones by some state employees, saying that Beijing had noted what it claimed were security concerns about the device.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Strikes Russia’s Black Sea Fleet
description: Plus a road trip in Mongolia.
content: A Ukrainian attack targeting the headquarters of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet in Crimea yesterday damaged two ships and triggered a large blaze at a sprawling naval shipyard, Russian and Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Pandemic Was a Time Machine
description: We have to come to terms with 20-year setbacks in a time of rapid, if uneven, progress.
content: Recently I came across perhaps the most mind-bending chart about the pandemic I’d seen over three-plus years. Originally published two years ago in The British Medical Journal, it shows how Covid affected age-standardized mortality in England and Wales — a statistic that controls for demographic change in measuring death rates, so that a country doesn’t look as if it’s getting sicker just because it’s getting older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
title: Morocco’s Quake Zone Now Fears for Its Livelihood, Too
description: The towns and villages of the Atlas Mountains were building a thriving tourist economy. The devastation of the earthquake puts that in doubt.
content: Before the tourists came to marvel at the valley cradled in Morocco’s Atlas Mountains, with its arid red slopes splashed with lush green and its deep-blue lake, the only living to be made was in olive farming, and not much of a living at that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: A Fugitive’s Capture Brings Relief to a Corner of Pennsylvania
description: After escaping from a county jail last month, Danelo Cavalcante eluded hundreds of law enforcement officers for nearly two weeks.
content: After nearly two weeks of combing the cornfields and forests of Chester County, Pa., with hundreds of law enforcement officers and a battery of drones, dogs and helicopters, the capture itself took about five minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: What Does America Owe the Victims of Racial Terrorism?
description: On the 60th anniversary of a K.K.K. bombing, Sarah Collins Rudolph is still seeking restitution.
content: I met Sarah Collins Rudolph, a small woman nestled into a corded khaki sofa, last month in her darkened living room in Birmingham, Ala. The room is something of a shrine, commemorating the 1963 act of terror that killed four little girls but spared a fifth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Fans Bet Their Bar Tabs on the Jets Losing. It Wasn’t a Safe Bet.
description: A bar in Wisconsin, where Aaron Rodgers played for years, offered free drinks if the New York Jets lost on Monday. But after a surprising comeback, patrons were left to pay their tabs.
content: No matter how good a bet may sound, remember: The house always wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Alyce McFadden
title: Trump Has Been Privately Encouraging G.O.P. Lawmakers to Impeach Biden
description: The former president has talked regularly with members of the House Freedom Caucus and other congressional Republicans who pushed for impeachment.
content: On a sweeping patio overlooking the golf course at his private club in Bedminster, N.J., former President Donald J. Trump dined Sunday night with a close political ally, Marjorie Taylor Greene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson Plan: The End of Race-Based Affirmative Action in College Admissions
description: In June the Supreme Court rejected race-conscious admissions. What will this mean for colleges and students?
content: Featured Article: “Supreme Court Rejects Affirmative Action Programs at Harvard and U.N.C.” by Adam Liptak
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Days of Wine and Roses’ Musical to Open on Broadway This Winter
description: Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James will reprise the roles they played Off Broadway earlier this year.
content: “Days of Wine and Roses,” a musical adaptation of a midcentury story about a loving marriage destroyed by alcoholism, will come to Broadway early next year starring the acclaimed stage performers Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: What Is Your Reaction to the End of Race-Based Affirmative Action in College Admissions?
description: To what degree, if any, do you think race should be considered when colleges decide which applicants to admit?
content: Since the 1960s, some colleges and universities have used race (a practice called affirmative action) as one of many criteria when deciding which students to admit. First, in the 1960s, some colleges wanted to open doors to Black students that had previously been closed because of longstanding racial discrimination. Later, many colleges considered an applicant’s race in an effort to create diverse student bodies. This summer, however, the Supreme Court ruled that race can no longer be used as part of the college admissions process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Tech Leaders Gather for an A.I. Week in Washington
description: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Sam Altman are among the moguls meeting with lawmakers to discuss how to regulate the fast-growing technology.
content: Artificial intelligence is again in focus this week in Washington, as leading tech executives — including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, Sundar Pichai, Satya Nadella and Sam Altman — as well as labor leaders and civil society groups meet on Wednesday with lawmakers behind closed doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Lazy Days
description: Do you enjoy lounging around?
content: These last weeks of summer are “one last chance to be lazy” says a Times writer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The Battle to Save Marilyn Monroe’s Last Home
description: The Los Angeles City Council has saved the actress’s Brentwood home from demolition — temporarily. Sixty years after her death there from an overdose, fans still leave flowers at the gate.
content: When Marilyn Monroe moved to Brentwood in 1962, the Los Angeles neighborhood provided the perfect seclusion for the world’s most famous woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Defying Industry, California Lawmakers Vote for Employer-Paid Food Training
description: The legislation would require state employers — not workers — to pay for mandatory safety instruction. It awaits the governor’s decision.
content: The California Legislature is moving to require employers to compensate food service employees for the cost of food safety training mandated by the state’s public health laws. If signed into law, the legislation would overturn a common practice in which employees cover the expense of obtaining the certification themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Olivia Natt, Sydney Harper, Devon Taylor, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: A New Covid Shot for a New Covid Era
description: During an uptick in infections, the U.S. government has recommended a new annual vaccination.
content: On Tuesday afternoon, the U.S. government recommended that almost every American begin taking a new annual vaccine for Covid, a milestone in the nation’s three-year battle against the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Unhappy Hour’: U.K. Pub Chains Adopt Surge Pricing for Pints
description: Britain’s largest pub company is charging more for drinks during weekends and evenings.
content: A pint of beer may cost more during peak hours at some pubs owned by Britain’s largest pub company, which has in recent weeks adopted surge pricing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Singing Competition Again Comes Under Fire After Use of Blackface
description: Contestants on a recent episode of a Polish reality TV show used blackface to imitate Kendrick Lamar and Beyoncé. It was not the first time the racist tradition had been featured.
content: A reality TV singing competition in Poland is under fire after two contestants used blackface to imitate Kendrick Lamar and Beyoncé during an episode that aired over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: In Antitrust Trial, Former Google Employee Details History of Search Deals
description: In the first full day of testimony in the U.S. monopoly trial against Google, the Justice Department sought to show that the company had long tried to cut out search competitors.
content: The Justice Department used its first full day of questioning in its antitrust trial against Google on Wednesday to establish that the internet giant had long sought agreements to be the default search engine on mobile devices, which the government argues were used to illegally maintain the company’s hold over online search.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: LOVE Is Back in New York, Restored
description: A familiar sculpture has returned with new paint and is now in Rockefeller Center. Also, the season can’t get much more dismal for New York sports fans.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a word that’s very large (even though it’s only four letters long) and is back in New York. We’ll also look at the latest indication that this isn’t the year for most New York sports teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Michael Cunningham Couldn’t Help but Write a Pandemic Novel
description: His new book, “Day,” is his first in nearly a decade. “How does anybody,” he said, “write a contemporary novel that’s about human beings that’s not about the pandemic?”
content: Michael Cunningham has a gnawing suspicion that his books are boring. He can’t shake the feeling, he said, not even four decades and eight novels into his career, not even after winning a Pulitzer Prize and selling millions of copies of “The Hours.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: In Show of Force, Silicon Valley Titans Pledge ‘Getting This Right’ With A.I.
description: Elon Musk, Sam Altman, Mark Zuckerberg, Sundar Pichai and others discussed artificial intelligence with lawmakers, as tech companies strive to influence potential regulations.
content: Elon Musk warned of civilizational risks posed by artificial intelligence. Sundar Pichai of Google highlighted the technology’s potential to solve health and energy problems. And Mark Zuckerberg of Meta stressed the importance of open and transparent A.I. systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: One Dead in Botulism Outbreak Traced to Sardines at Bar in France
description: At least a dozen people became ill after eating at a popular organic wine bar in Bordeaux. Health officials blamed contaminated homemade preserves.
content: A woman has died and at least a dozen other people have become ill with botulism in France after eating homemade sardine preserves at a wine bar in the southwestern city of Bordeaux, French officials said on Wednesday, as they warned that other cases could soon come to light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Sheds Hundreds of Recruiters in Another Round of Layoffs
description: The tech giant has sought to trim expenses to pay for artificial intelligence investments; it had earlier cut 12,000 jobs in January.
content: Google conducted another round of layoffs on Wednesday, telling its recruiters that by the end of the day hundreds of them would be losing their jobs, three people with knowledge of the layoffs said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David DeSteno
title: Rosh Hashana Can Change Your Life (Even if You’re Not Jewish)
description: The holiday has an important lesson for everyone.
content: Celebrating a new year — as Jews the world over will do this week, when Rosh Hashana begins on Friday at sunset — is all about making changes. It’s a time for new beginnings, for wiping the slate clean and starting over from scratch. In that spirit, on Rosh Hashana Jews say prayers and listen to readings that celebrate the creation of the world and of human life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: You Can’t Have One Without the Other
description: Cleveland Guardians pitchers Lucas Giolito and Reynaldo López met as teenagers in 2012 and have been together ever since, with stops with four organizations.
content: They are from different parts of the world. They have different backgrounds and fill different roles on a pitching staff. They are both 29 and have pitched for four different major league organizations. Each has been traded twice and waived once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Brazilian and Sharon Radisch
title: Why Artists Can’t Quit Cigarettes
description: A symbol of dirty habits and corporate greed — and an enduring icon of old-school glamour — smoking is making an unlikely comeback in sculpture, design and even food.
content: This past spring, Andrew Gori, 40, and Ambre Kelly, 44, the founders of the Spring/Break Art Show — a fair for emerging and midcareer artists — decided to pull together a last-minute, salon-style pop-up in New York’s NoLIta based on what their “alums had available in their studios right at that moment,” Gori says. As the submissions rolled in, one trend stood out: “There were so many cigarettes!” So many, in fact, that when their “Secret Show” opened in May, one room was dedicated entirely to cigarette-inspired art: There were nearly three-foot-high versions that resembled shaggy plush toys, made by Thomas Martinez-Pilnik, 29. There were sculptures in a variety of stubbed-out shapes constructed from steel by Mary Gagler, and clay by Emily Marchand. And on a 4-by-5-foot square of AstroTurf, 17 true-to-scale ceramic butts by Taylor Lee Nicholson, 32, were scattered like the contents of an overturned ashtray. “For these artists, cigarettes seem to represent childhood memories of their parents or grandparents smoking, but also a lost human connection,” Gori says. “I think there’s a yearning to return to an analog socialness and a time that cigarettes represent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Choe Sang-Hun
title: Summit Signals How Ukraine War Drives Russian Foreign Policy
description: The backdrop of the war has made North Korea more relevant than in years past for Russia, despite the North’s history as an impoverished, sometimes troublesome partner.
content: The summit meeting on Wednesday between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, comes at a rare moment of mutual need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes, Alexis Soloski, Brittani Samuel and Rhoda Feng
title: Four Theater Artists to Watch This Fall
description: We spoke with two actors and two playwrights who will be in the spotlight this season.
content: The playwright Emma Horwitz has lived in New York most of her life. The scent of the city is the scent of her memories — or the reek, depending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Giang
title: Arm, the Chip Designer, Raises $4.87 Billion in the Year’s Largest I.P.O.
description: Arm’s return to public markets is being watched, by both Wall Street and Silicon Valley, as a barometer of investor appetite for new tech offerings.
content: Arm, the British chip design company whose technology has been essential to nearly all mobile phones, raised $4.87 billion in an initial public offering, it said on Wednesday. Arm’s I.P.O. is the largest this year, and values the company at $54.5 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Peter C. Newman, 94, Journalist and Scourge of Canada’s Powerful, Dies
description: A historian as well, he challenged, with a muckraker’s spirit, the political and corporate establishment of a country he adopted after fleeing Nazi-occupied Europe.
content: Peter C. Newman, a maverick journalist and historian who skewered the political establishment in Canada while evolving into a fervent nationalist there, his adopted country, to which he had fled as a boy from Nazi-occupied Europe, died on Sept. 7 in Belleville, in southeast Ontario. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘No Good Things Dwell in the Flesh’ Review: Seeking a Successor
description: In her new play, Christina Masciotti turns a keen gaze on an immigrant tailor who has woven her business into the fabric of a neighborhood.
content: Inside an unassuming storefront somewhere in Queens is a woman you wouldn’t notice if you saw her on the street. The drape, fit and feel of clothes are her passion and her living, but her own outfit is pallid, frumpy — a kind of camouflage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Our Five-Star Shakshuka With 15,000 Reviews
description: More back-to-school boosts: quick chicken noodle soup, bright tofu larb and chocolate chip brookies.
content: Eating breakfast for dinner is always a comfort, especially when back-to-school season is roiling schedules, routines and nerves. It’s time to sink into the familiar embrace of old favorites, like my shakshuka with feta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Colorado’s First Michelin Restaurant Guide Serves Up Few Stars
description: The French arbiter of fine dining gave a single star to each of five restaurants, fewer than what other regions have won, after tourism officials lobbied for a guide in the state.
content: Five restaurants in Colorado — three in Denver, one in Aspen and one in Boulder — each won a Michelin star on Tuesday night, and no two- or three-star restaurants were anointed by the influential culinary guide in its first round of awards in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Deputy Treasury Secretary to Visit Nigeria to Bolster Economic Ties
description: Wally Adeyemo, the highest-ranking member of the African diaspora in the Biden administration, emigrated from Nigeria to the United States as a child.
content: The Biden administration is dispatching Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, to Nigeria next week as it seeks to deepen economic ties with Africa and counter China’s influence on the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Chorin
title: The Unimaginable Has Happened in Libya
description: The United States has a unique moral obligation to help in the aftermath of Libya’s disaster.
content: This week, the worst storm in recent memory pounded the Green Mountains in eastern Libya with rain, pushing two poorly maintained, half-century-old dams to their limit. Just before 3 a.m. on Sept. 11, the first dam collapsed. An enormous wall of water surged into a riverbed that bisects the coastal city of Derna. It stalled briefly at the second dam eight miles downstream and then scooped that and everything else up in its path, tossing the debris into the sea. By dawn, a third of the city was gone, leaving thousands missing. The number of dead may reach as high as 10,000, Libyan aid coordinators say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Police Captured an Escaped Killer in Pennsylvania
description: Also, Mitt Romney says he will retire in 2025. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: A convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison and spent two weeks hiding in woods and fields was captured this morning, ending an extensive manhunt through Philadelphia’s western suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: Jim Nutt’s Art Remains a Mystery. Even to Him.
description: In his first show of new work in over a decade, he has been occupied with a single subject: a portrait of a woman, in which he finds endless variation and human emotion.
content: They look at you from behind inscrutable eyes, aloof and moderately annoyed, jawlines jutting like ice floes. The faces are at once classically familiar and deeply strange, like Northern Renaissance portraiture pushed through a Cubist sieve, Hans Memling’s “Portrait of Barbara van Vlaendenbergh” worked over with a tire iron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Melissa Eddy
title: European Union Will Investigate Chinese Subsidies of Electric Cars
description: The European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, announced the inquiry, which could lead to tariffs, amid concern over China’s dominance in electric vehicles.
content: The European Union will begin an investigation into Chinese subsidies of electric vehicles, the bloc’s top official announced Wednesday, in a move that highlights Europe’s growing industrial and geopolitical competition with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Behold: New York City’s Trash Can of the Future
description: Generations in the making, the new, sleeker receptacles will soon replace the iconic green mesh bins.
content: Coming to a street corner near you: a sleek new litter basket, the latest weapon in New York City’s generations-long war on trash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Larry Chance, Who Helped Keep Doo-Wop Alive for Decades, Dies at 82
description: His career began in 1957, when he and some friends from the Bronx formed the vocal group that would become the Earls. He recorded his last song 65 years later.
content: Larry Chance, whose Bronx vocal group the Earls was one of the most enduring acts of the doo-wop era, helping to keep alive the vocal harmonies, rhythmic syllables and onomatopoeic lyrics that had once been improvised on city street corners and in subway stations, died on Sept. 6 in a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 13, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 13, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the late arrival of rescuers for some Moroccan earthquake victims transposed the given and family names of a village resident. He is Omar Ouchahed, not Ouchahed Omar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Apply to the New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship
description: Submissions will be open from Oct. 4 until Nov. 10.
content: The New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor fellowship provides mentorship and support for constructors from underrepresented groups, including women, people of color and the L.G.B.T.Q. community. We want our puzzles to reflect the reality of all Americans, which means publishing work that displays a wide range of cultural reference points, language usage and communities. The fellowship is for constructors who have not yet been published by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: An Economic Case Against Environmental Doomsayers
description: Amid the rise of the degrowth movement, two authors argue for the necessity of abundance.
content: Judging from the emails I get, a lot of readers of this newsletter are sympathetic to the degrowth movement, which holds that humanity must suppress economic and population growth to save the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Klein
title: To Know Yourself, Consider Your Doppelgänger
description: Our doubles show us parts of ourselves we can least bear to see, at a slight angle, and through a warped mirror.
content: This past July, Merriam-Webster announced on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, that “‘doppelgänger’ is currently one of our top lookups.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: A Viable Alternative to Conventional Lawn? Cornell May Have Found One.
description: Cornell Botanic Gardens is testing sustainable options for replacing your backyard grass. The bonus: They don’t need to be cut more than twice a year.
content: It’s a grail of contemporary horticulture, a subject of inquiry for scientists and landscape designers alike: how to reinvent the estimated 40 million acres of lawn in the United States, shifting the emphasis toward native plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Prepares for Limited Strike Against Detroit Automakers on Friday
description: The union’s president, Shawn Fain, said negotiators were nowhere near an agreement and ruled out a contract extension while talks continued.
content: Barely 24 hours before the contract deadline, the United Auto Workers leader said Wednesday that his members were prepared for a strike against the three Detroit automakers — first at a limited number of factories, with the walkout expanding if talks remain bogged down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: More suspected Russian drone debris is found in Romania.
description: The NATO member said it was the third such discovery in less than two weeks.
content: Romania found more debris suspected to be from a Russian drone on Wednesday, following Russian strikes on Ukrainian Danube ports just across the border. It was the third such discovery on Romanian soil in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Wirecutter Editors Learned from the 2023 Apple Event
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shirley Ngozi Nwangwa
title: On View: A Coffin That Connects Multiple Black Histories
description: In a new solo exhibition, Awol Erizku’s hip-hop-centric works are touched by “so many spirits.”
content: In a new solo exhibition, Awol Erizku’s hip-hop-centric works are touched by “so many spirits.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Manning and Brian Turner
title: How to Fall in Love With the World Again
description: A visual meditation on loss and finding comfort in the natural world.
content: A visual meditation on loss and finding comfort in the natural world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
description: The Saratoga Race Course has long been a big draw, but it’s not the only one in this small, walkable city with a ‘phenomenal quality of life.’
content: The Saratoga Race Course has long been a big draw, but it’s not the only one in this small, walkable city with a ‘phenomenal quality of life.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Fire Erupts at Hanoi Apartment Building
description: Local reports said the fire was hard to contain because the building is in a narrow alley.
content: Local reports said the fire was hard to contain because the building is in a narrow alley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: McCarthy Reverses Position on Impeachment Inquiry
description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy ordered an impeachment inquiry against President Biden without approval by the full House, reversing his previous position.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy ordered an impeachment inquiry against President Biden without approval by the full House, reversing his previous position.
source.name: The New York Times
